# Challenge Code
```
from Crypto.Util.number import bytes_to_long, getPrime

FLAG = <REDACTED>

p = getPrime(1024)
q = getPrime(1024)
e = 0x10001
n = p * q
m = bytes_to_long(FLAG)

c = pow(m, e, n)
t1 = pow(p + q, e, n)
t2 = pow(p - q, e, n)

print(f"n = {n}")
print(f"c = {c}")
print(f"t1 = {t1}")
print(f"t2 = {t2}")

# n = 
# c = 
# t1 = 
# t2 = 
```

# Solution
We've been given `t1` and `t2` with `p+q` and `p-q` within it.

With that, we can do binomial expension.
<br>$t1 = (p+q)^e \mod N$
<br>$t1 = p^e + q^e \mod N$
<br>$-p^e = -t1 + q^e \mod N$ -- equation 1

<br>$t2 = (p+q)^e \mod N$
<br>$t2 = p^e + q^e \mod N$
<br>$-p^e = -t2 + q^e \mod N$ -- equation 2

Combine equation 1 and equation 2
<br>$-t1 + q^e \mod N = -t2 + q^e \mod N$
<br>$2q^e = t1-t2 \mod N$ 
<br>$q^e = \frac{t1-t2}{2} \mod N$ 

Ok gret! we got $q^e$ now. 
We can actually get `p` here by reducing `q^e` and `N`.

<br>$q^e \mod N$  
<br>$= q^e  + kN$ 
<br>$= q(q^(e-1) + kp)$
<br>Therefore $q | q^e \mod N$

To execute this, we do $p = \gcd{(p^e,}{N)}$

With `p` and `q`, just do normal decryption, calculate `phi_n` and `d`.

```
n = 
c = 
t1 = 
t2 = 
e = 0x10001

from Crypto.Util.number import long_to_bytes
def gcd(x, y):
    while(y):
       x, y = y, x % y
    return abs(x)

two_qe = ((t1-t2)) % n
p = gcd(two_qe,n)
q = n//p

phi_n = (p-1)*(q-1)
d = pow(e,-1,phi_n)

m = pow(c,d,n)
print(long_to_bytes(m))
```
